keywords: RBT, GIS tools, ESRI ArcGIS Desktop, DEM, river channels, hydraulic geometry, cross sections, profile analysis, water depths, fish habitat.
abstract:
The RBT (River Basin Tools) is a set of GIS tools designed for use within ESRI's ArcGIS Desktop software. These tools enable users to analyze and measure river channels using high-resolution Digital Elevation Models (DEMs). DEMs can be obtained from various sources, such as airborne LiDAR or ground-based surveys.

The RBT offers several useful functionalities:
1. It enables users to remove the longitudinal valley slope from a DEM, allowing for more accurate analysis.
2. Users can cut custom cross sections through the DEM to examine the hydraulic geometry of a river, such as bankfull width and depth.
3. The RBT computes stream gradient and sinuosity.
4. Long profiles can be created along the length of a channel to analyze longitudinal variations in channel geometry metrics.
5. By changing the water level in a detrended DEM, users can investigate water depths within a river and identify off-channel habitats still hydraulically connected to the main stem flow.
6. Residual pools can be located using the RBT, which may help identify fish habitats.

It's important to note that you need to have ArcGIS installed before you can use the RBT tools. For further details about collecting measurement data for this analysis, refer to the CHaMP - Topographic Point Collection Methods document at http://www.monitoringmethods.org/Method/Details/836.

The RBT generates the thalweg (the deepest part of a river channel) using a method outlined in detail at https://www.monitoringmethods.org/Method/Details/2767. This method is necessary as accurately determining the thalweg is crucial for understanding the hydraulic behavior and morphology of a river system. By identifying the thalweg, users can gain insights into water flow patterns, flood risk assessments, and potential habitats for aquatic organisms.
description:
The River Bathtub (RBT) is a collection of ArcGIS tools designed for analyzing and measuring river channels using Digital Elevation Models (DEMs). These DEMs can be obtained from various sources, including airborne remote sensing techniques like LiDAR or ground-based topographic surveys. The RBT extension, which requires the installation of ESRI ArcGIS Desktop software, offers several functionalities:

1. Detrending a DEM: This process eliminates longitudinal valley slope to enable accurate analysis and comparison of channel features.
2. User-defined cross sections: These allow you to extract specific data from the detrended DEMs at desired locations.
3. Hydraulic geometry definition: You can define attributes like bankfull width/depth in each cross section for comprehensive analysis.
4. Computing stream gradient and sinuosity: The RBT provides tools for calculating these essential channel characteristics.
5. Longitudinal profiles: You can generate long profiles along the length of a channel to analyze variations in channel geometry metrics.
6. Water level investigation: By varying water levels in detrended DEMs, you can assess the distribution of water depths inside a stream and identify off-channel habitats still hydraulically connected to the main stem flow.
7. Residual pool location: This feature helps identify potential fish habitats by locating residual pools within the analyzed data.

Additionally, it's essential to note that accurate measurement data is crucial for utilizing the RBT tools effectively. The Collection of Hydrometric Data - Topographic Point Collection Methods (CHaMP) provides valuable background information on collecting such data (<http://www.monitoringmethods.org/Method/Details/836>). Furthermore, the thalweg (the deepest point in a river channel during normal flow conditions) is generated using a specific method described at <https://www.monitoringmethods.org/Method/Details/2767>.
